body:
Comment 5 by **per.arneng**: 
> The ms.net example does not have specific sections for parameter and return values.

If you click any method you have a page dedicated to that method that shows syntax
and under that you can see parameters and return values. Each exception is also
documented. There is also example code on how to use each method. The .NET framework
is probably the best documented API in the world ( And i am a linux guy :-) )

> My own opinion is that separate parameter and return value pieces just encourage 
> long-winded documentation.  

I think that the most important information is the parameters, return values and any
exceptions. It is usually possible to understand what the method does by just looking
at the name so then it is good to also see if anything special is to be taken in to
consideration for the parameters and return values.

Another advantage of have special handling for documentation of parameters and return
values is that IDE's can parse that documentation and show it to you live as you are
writing code that calls you method for the specific parameter you are typing at the
moment. Eclipse is doing this with the Java doc.

> For me at least godoc is working great as is.

Most system's programming people today are Java developers (JEE) and they are used to
this kind of documentation. I think that this is not an extremely important thing to
have but it would probably make the transition for a Java developer in to Go much
easier. 

Learning a new language goes pretty fast since it is often just smaller syntax
difference for the same kinds of features but it is the API that takes time to learn.

Doxygen is a another documentation generator with support for alot of languages:
http://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/
Sample:
http://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/api/html/group__DBusHashTable.html#gfde7b61c232d93e5120bc183e1721e73

Maybe this is a project for Google's summer of code?
